keyTakeAways: A daylight robbery at the Louvre Museum in Paris, involving four masked thieves, resulted in the theft of high-value jewellery, including items from Napoleon’s and Empress Eugenie’s collections.
The stolen items are estimated to be worth €88 million, with experts emphasizing that the greatest loss is to France's historical and cultural heritage.
The thieves used a truck equipped with a mechanical lift and battery-powered disc cutter to gain entry, cutting through a glass window and threatening guards, before fleeing on scooters.
A damaged crown formerly worn by Empress Eugenie was found on the escape route, suggesting the thieves fled in haste.
Security failures were identified, including the absence of CCTV in one-third of rooms and a failure of the alarm system to activate.
The French government, including President Emmanuel Macron and Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin, condemned the attack as a serious threat to national heritage.
Investigators believe the thieves are professionals due to the speed and coordination of the heist.
Experts warn that the stolen jewellery is likely already melted down into precious metals and sold abroad for a fraction of its value.
Prosecutor Laure Beccuau stated that the stolen items' value may deter the robbers from destroying them, as doing so would forfeit financial gain.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In a daring daylight heist at the Louvre Museum in Paris, four masked thieves stole high-value jewellery—such as a necklace from Napoleon I and a tiara from Empress Eugenie—within eight minutes of the museum opening. The stolen items, valued at €88 million, represent a significant loss to France's cultural heritage. Security failures were identified, including missing CCTV and a failed alarm system. The thieves used a truck with a mechanical lift and a battery-powered disc cutter to enter the museum, threatening guards and fleeing on scooters. A damaged crown was found on the escape route. Experts believe the stolen items have likely been melted down and sold abroad. French leaders, including President Emmanuel Macron and Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin, condemned the attack as an attack on national heritage and called for improved security. Authorities suspect professionals due to the speed and coordination of the crime, and experts warn there is less than two days to recover the items before they are lost forever.
title: Louvre heist: Stolen jewellery worth €88m, prosecutor says
